Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery band-cup; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of seated sphinx (lower body with added red and added white on chest and wing remaining) to left; to left of sphinx, incised palmette with red on petals and with tendril; at right of sphinx, part of standing spectator, with some red on his himation, and tail and hind leg of an animal (horse?); below, wide black band above reserved zone; modern inscription on exterior.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd is also published in Corbett and Woodhead, 'A forger of graffiti', ABSA 59 (1955) 261, no. 24 and the graffito is identified by the authors as a modern forgery. They argue that the graffiti were probably made in Athens as they bear strong similarities with a number of other forgeries there. The sherd was found presumably at Naukratis during Hogarth's excavations in 1899. Prior to his work there, Hogarth had worked in the British School at Athens in 1886-1888 and was the Director of the school between 1897 and 1900. Edgar, who published the catalogue of sherds from Hogarth's excavations at Naukratis, was also at the school in Athens between 1895 and 1898. Corbett and Woodhead suggest that one of the two may have acquired the sherd in Athens and accidentally kept it.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 39, pl. XX, no. 7)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1363) (phase 3)
